And at that time, Allah the Exalted fulfills His saying: 'Then We will surely question those to whom messengers were sent, and We will surely question the messengers. Indeed, You are the Knower of the unseen."' (Quran 5:109) Oh, the severity of a day in which the intellects (Aql) of the prophets are bewildered and their knowledges (Ilm) are erased from the intensity of the awe (Hiba) when it is said to them, 'What did you answer?' even though they were sent to the creation and they had known. So their intellects are stunned, and they do not know with what to answer, and they say from the intensity of the awe, 'We have no knowledge. Indeed, You are the Knower of the unseen.' And they at that time are truthful, since the intellects have flown from them and the knowledges have been erased until Allah the Exalted strengthens them.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
The Fourth Foundation: The Scale (Mizan) and it is truth. Allah the Exalted said: 'And We place the scales of justice for the Day of Resurrection' (Surah Al-Anbiya: 47). And He the Exalted said: 'So whoever's scales are heavy, then those are the successful ones. And whoever's scales are light' (Surah Al-Mu'minun: 102-103). And its explanation (wajhaha) is that Allah the Exalted creates in the records of deeds a weight (waznan) according to the degrees of deeds with Allah the Exalted, so the measures of the deeds of the servants become known to the servants until justice in punishment or favor in pardon and multiplication of reward becomes apparent to them.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
Afterwards, anger is a flame of fire borrowed from the fire of Allah the kindled which rises upon the hearts (Afa'idah), and indeed it is hidden in the fold of the heart (Fu'ad). The hiding of embers under ashes, and it is extracted by the concealed arrogance in the heart of every obstinate tyrant, like extracting fire from stone with iron, and it has been revealed to the observers with the light of certainty (Yaqin), that the human being has a vein extending to the accursed Satan (Shaytan), so whoever is provoked by the fire of anger has strengthened in him the kinship of Satan when he said "I am better than him, You created me from fire and created him from clay." For the nature of clay is stillness and dignity, and the nature of fire is blazing and flaming, and movement and agitation, and from the results of anger are malice (Haqd) and envy (Hasad), and by them perished whoever perished and corrupted whoever corrupted, and their source is a morsel (Mudghah) if it becomes sound, the entire body becomes sound with it, and if malice and envy and anger are among what drives the servant (Abd) to places of destruction, how much he needs to know its harms and evils! To beware of that and avoid it, and remove it from the heart if it exists and expel it, and treat it if it becomes entrenched in his heart and cure it, for whoever does not know evil falls into it, and whoever knows it, knowledge alone does not suffice him, unless he knows the path by which he repels evil and removes it.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
And the accursed one created from fire was commanded to settle from his movement prostrating to what Allah created from clay, but he refused and was arrogant and disobeyed, and he expressed the reason for his disobedience by saying: 'You created me from fire and created him from clay' (Quran 7:12). Therefore, since the accursed one did not prostrate to our father Adam (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), one should not hope for his prostration to his children. And these are corrupt analogies resembling the analogy of Iblis (Satan) when he said: "I am better than him (Adam), You created me from fire and created him from clay." And to these people is the reference in His saying, the Exalted: "Those are the ones who have purchased the worldly life for the Hereafter, so the punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be aided." And the treatment for this delusion (Ghurur) is either through affirmation of faith (Iman) or through proof (Burhan); as for affirmation through mere faith (Iman), it is to believe Allah, the Exalted, in His saying: "What is with you will be exhausted, and what is with Allah is enduring," and in His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: "And what is with Allah is better," and His saying: "And the Hereafter is better and more enduring," and His saying: "And the worldly life is not but the enjoyment of delusion (Ghurur)," and His saying: "So do not let the worldly life delude you." And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) informed groups of disbelievers of this, so they followed him and believed him and had faith (Amanu) in him and did not demand proof from him[3], and among them were those who said: "I adjure you by Allah, did Allah send you as a messenger?" And he would say: "Yes," so they would believe[4]. And this is the faith (Iman) of the common people, and it removes from delusion (Ghurur), and this is placed in the position of a child believing his father that attending the school is better than attending the playground, even though he does not know the aspect of its being better. And as for knowledge through clarification and proof (Burhan), it is to know the aspect of corruption of this analogy that Satan has organized in his heart (Qalb), for every deluded person has a cause for his delusion (Ghurur), and that cause is evidence, and every evidence is a type of analogy that occurs in the soul (Nafs) and produces tranquility (Sukun) towards it, even if its possessor is not aware of it nor capable of organizing it with the words of the scholars. Therefore, his arrogance toward the creation is great because it will lead him to arrogance toward the command of Allah. Indeed, Iblis (Satan) was made an example of this, and what is narrated of his states is only to take lesson from it. For he said: 'I am better than him,' and this arrogance is by lineage because he said: 'I am better than him; You created me from fire and created him from clay.' This carried him to refuse the prostration that Allah the Exalted commanded him to perform. Its beginning was arrogance toward Adam and envy of him, which dragged him to arrogance toward the command of Allah the Exalted, and that became the cause of his destruction forever. So this is a great affliction from the afflictions of arrogance upon the servants. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah ï·º explained arrogance by these two afflictions when Thabit ibn Qays ibn Shammas asked him: 'O Messenger of Allah, I am a man to whom beauty has become beloved as you see; is this from arrogance?' He ï·º said: 'No, but arrogance is from rejecting the truth (battar al-haqq) and despising people (ghamá¹£ al-nÄs).' And in another narration: 'from belittling the truth (safaha al-haqq).' And his saying 'and despising people' means looking down upon them and considering them insignificant, while they are servants of Allah like him or better than him. And this first affliction 'and belittling the truth' is rejecting it, and it is the second affliction. So whoever sees that he is better than his brother and despises his brother, looks down upon him, and views him with the eye of belittlement, or rejects the truth while knowing it, has become arrogant between himself and the creation. And whoever is too proud to submit to Allah the Exalted and humble himself to Allah through obedience and following His messengers has become arrogant between himself and Allah the Exalted and His messengers.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
Therefore, Allah warned all creation from him, so Allah the Exalted said: "O children of Adam, let not Satan tempt you as he removed your parents from the Garden (Jannah), stripping them of their clothing to show them their private parts. Indeed, he sees you, he and his tribe, from where you do not see them." And the Quran from its beginning to its end is a warning from Satan, so how [can one be heedless] when He has commanded caution from the enemy just as He commanded caution from the disbelievers? He the Exalted said: "And let them take their precaution and their weapons," and He the Exalted said: "And prepare against them whatever you are able of power and of steeds of war." So if it is incumbent upon you by Allah's command to be cautious from the disbelieving enemy whom you see, then it is more appropriate that it be incumbent upon you to be cautious from an enemy who sees you but you do not see him.

Rather, I say that listening to strings from one who plays them without proportional rhythm that is pleasurable is also forbidden, and by this it becomes clear that the reason for their prohibition is not merely the pleasant pleasure, but the analogy is the permissibility of all good things except what in its permissibility contains corruption. Allah the Exalted said: 'Say, who has forbidden the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants and the good things from the provision?' So these sounds are not forbidden because they are rhythmic sounds, but rather they are forbidden due to another incidental factor, as will come in the forbidden incidents of the third degree: the rhythmic and comprehensible, which is poetry, and that does not come out except from the throat of a human, so it is decisively permissible because it only increased by being comprehensible, and comprehensible speech is not forbidden, and pleasant rhythmic sound is not forbidden. So if the individual elements are not forbidden, then from where is the combination forbidden? Yes, one looks at what is understood from it; if it contains a prohibited matter, its prose and poetry are forbidden, and speaking it is forbidden whether with melodies or not. The truth in it is what Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said when he said: 'Poetry is speech, so its good is good and its bad is bad.' Whenever reciting poetry without voice and melodies is permissible, reciting it with melodies is permissible, for when permissible individual things gather, that combination is permissible, and whenever a permissible thing joins with a permissible thing, it is not forbidden except if the combination contains a prohibition that the individual elements do not contain, and there is no prohibition here. And how can reciting poetry be denied when it was recited in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him? The hadith of reciting poetry in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, is agreed upon from the narration of Abu Hurairah that 'Umar passed by Hassan while he was reciting poetry in the mosque, so he glanced at him and said: 'I used to recite, and in it is one better than you,' the hadith, and in Muslim from the narration of 'A'isha, reciting.

We add and say: If he remained alive until the time of one prayer entered upon him and he abandoned it, then died, or committed adultery then died - is he eternally punished in the Fire? If he says yes, then this is the intent of the Mu'tazilites; and if he says no, then this is a clear statement that action is not a pillar of the essence of faith, nor a condition for its existence, nor for deserving Paradise through it.

For he has not been annihilated with an annihilation that prevents remembrance, but rather with an annihilation from the worldly life and the realm of dominion and witness, not from the realm of sovereignty. And to what we have mentioned is the allusion in his saying ï­¬: (The grave is either a pit from the pits of Hell or a garden from the gardens of Paradise[58]) and in his saying ï­¬: (The spirits of the martyrs are in the crops of green birds[59]) and in his saying ï­¬ to the slain of Badr from the polytheists: (O so-and-so and O so-and-soâ€”and the Prophet ï­¬ named themâ€”'Have you found what your Lord promised you to be true? He said ï­¬: 'By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, you are not more hearing of my speech than them, but they are not able to respond.') And the hadith is in the Sahih; this is his saying ï­¬ regarding the polytheists. a.g: Who averted [people] from the way of Allah and sought to make it [seem] deviant while they were, concerning the Hereafter, disbelievers.

And between them will be a partition, and on [its] elevations are men who recognize all by their mark. And they call out to the companions of Paradise, "Peace be upon you." They have not [yet] entered it, but they long intensely.
And when their eyes are turned toward the companions of the Fire, they say, "Our Lord, do not place us with the wrongdoing people."
And the companions of the Elevations will call to men [within Hell] whom they recognize by their mark, saying, "Of no avail to you was your gathering and [the fact] that you were arrogant."

[Allah will say], "Are these the ones whom you [inhabitants of Hell] swore that Allah would never offer them mercy? Enter Paradise, [O People of the Elevations]. No fear will there be concerning you, nor will you grieve."

And the companions of the Fire will call to the companions of Paradise, "Pour upon us some water or from whatever Allah has provided you." They will say, "Indeed, Allah has forbidden them both to the disbelievers."

Vol 2: Etiquette of Travel
Indeed, sleep [nawm] is a minor death [wafat sughra], and wakefulness [yaqazah] is a minor resurrection [ba'th asghar]. So just as the dead are resurrected from their graves, likewise the sleepers are resurrected from their beds. Therefore, it is incumbent upon the servant ['abd] that he remember at the time of his sleep that he is dying for a time, and that he is resurrected upon his awakening, so that this may be a reminder for him of the Hereafter [al-akhirah] and an alert to the majesty of the Creator. And for that reason, it is recommended that he recite upon sleeping verses that remind of Allah, the Exalted, and His Oneness [tawhid], such as His saying, the Exalted: **"Indeed, your Lord is Allah who created the heavens and the earth in six days..."** For in this reminder of the creation of the heavens and the earth in six days is an indication of the power [qudrah] of Allah, the Exalted, and His majesty, and that He is the Lord [al-Rabb], the Manager, who takes the souls [anfus] in their sleep and resurrects them. Thus, the servant senses with that his humility [tawadu'] and his submission [khushu'], and he prepares for sleep as he prepares for death, so he sleeps in a state of purity [taharah] and remembrance [dhikr], facing the Qiblah, supplicating to his Lord that He protect him in his sleep just as He protects him in his wakefulness.

Allah the Exalted said: 'And when My servants ask you concerning Me, indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me. So let them respond to Me' (Quran 2:186). And He said: 'Call upon your Lord humbly (tadarru'an) and in secret (khufyatan). Indeed, He does not like the transgressors' (Quran 7:55). And He said: 'And your Lord says, "Call upon Me; I will respond to you. Indeed, those who disdain My worship will enter Hell in humiliation"' (Quran 40:60). And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Say, "Call upon Allah or call upon the Most Merciful. Whichever [name] you call - to Him belong the best names"' (Quran 17:110). Then he recited: 'Call upon Me; I will respond to you' (Quran 40:60) [65]). And he (peace be upon him) said: ('Supplication (Du'a) is the marrow of worship (mukhkh al-'Ibadah) [66]'). And Abu Hurairah narrated that he (peace be upon him) said: ('Nothing is more honorable to Allah the Mighty and Majestic than supplication (Du'a) [67]'). And he (peace be upon him) said: ('The servant (al-'Abd) does not miss from supplication (Du'a) one of three things: either a sin (dhamb) is forgiven for him, or a good (khayr) is hastened for him, or a good (khayr) is stored for him [68]'). And Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with him) said: 'Sufficient for supplication (Du'a) with righteousness (al-Birr) is what suffices food from salt.' Fourth: Lowering the voice between whispering and loudness, as narrated that Abu Musa al-Ash'ari said: We arrived with the Messenger of Allah, and when we approached Medina, he said 'Allahu Akbar' and the people said 'Allahu Akbar' and raised their voices. The Prophet said: (O people, the One you call upon is not deaf nor absent; the One you call upon is between you and the necks of your mounts). And Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said regarding His saying, the Exalted: (And do not be loud in your prayer nor whisper it) meaning in your supplication. And Allah, the Exalted, praised His prophet Zakariya, peace be upon him, when He said: (When he called upon his Lord with a secret call). And the Exalted said: (Call upon your Lord humbly and secretly). Fifth: That one should not contrive rhymed prose in supplication, for the state of the supplicant should be a state of humility (mutadarriÊ¿), and contrivance does not suit it. He said: (There will be a people who exceed bounds in supplication). And the Exalted said: (Call upon your Lord humbly and secretly; indeed, He does not love the transgressors). It is said its meaning is contrivance for rhymed prose, and it is preferable not to go beyond the transmitted supplications, for one may transgress in his supplication and ask for what his benefit does not require, for not everyone is good at supplication. Therefore, it is narrated from Mu'adh, may Allah be pleased with him, that the scholars are needed in Paradise, for it will be said to the people of Paradise: 'Wish,' and they will not know how to wish until they learn from the scholars. And he said: (Beware of rhymed prose in supplication; it is enough for one of you to say: O Allah, I ask You for Paradise and what brings near to it of speech and action, and I seek refuge in You from the Fire and what brings near to it of speech and action). And in the report: 'There will come a people who exceed bounds in supplication and purification.' And some of the predecessors passed by a storyteller supplicating with rhymed prose and said to him: 'May Allah elevate your exaggeration, I bear witness that I saw Habib al-'Ajami supplicating, and he did not exceed saying: O Allah, make us good, O Allah, do not disgrace us on the Day of Resurrection, O Allah, grant us success in good,' and the people were supplicating from every direction behind him, and he was known for the blessing of his supplication. And some of them said: 'Supplicate with the tongue of humility (dhull) and neediness (iftiqar), not with the tongue of eloquence and fluency.'

Fifth: That one should not force rhymed prose in supplication, for the state of the supplicant should be a state of humility, and affectation does not suit it. The Prophet ï·º said: 'There will be a people who transgress in supplication.' And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Call upon your Lord with humility and in secret. Indeed, He does not love the transgressors.' It is said its meaning is affectation for rhymed prose. And it is preferable not to go beyond the transmitted supplications, for one may transgress in his supplication and ask for what his benefit does not require, and not everyone is good at supplication. And in the report: 'There will come a people who transgress in supplication and purification.' And some of the predecessors passed by a storyteller supplicating with rhymed prose and said to him: 'May Allah elevate your exaggeration; I bear witness that I saw Habib al-'Ajami supplicating and he did not exceed saying: O Allah, make us good, O Allah, do not disgrace us on the Day of Resurrection, O Allah, grant us success in good.' Vol 2: Etiquette of Earning a Livelihood
And Allah the Exalted has commanded justice and excellence in conduct (Ihsan) together. Justice is only the cause of salvation, and it flows in trade like capital. Excellence in conduct (Ihsan) is the cause of triumph and attainment of happiness, and it flows in trade like profit. One is not considered among the heedless who is content in worldly transactions with his capital, likewise in the transactions of the Hereafter. So it is not fitting for the religious person to limit himself to justice and avoiding oppression and abandon the doors of excellence in conduct (Ihsan). And Allah has said: 'And do good as Allah has done good to you' (28:77). And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Indeed, Allah commands justice and excellence in conduct (Ihsan)' (16:90). And He the Glorified said: 'Indeed, the mercy of Allah is near to the doers of good (Al-Muhsinin)' (7:56). And we mean by excellence in conduct (Ihsan) doing what benefits the other party in transaction, and it is not obligatory upon him, but it is a favor from him. For the obligatory enters into the category of justice and avoiding oppression, and we have mentioned it.

And let us return to the intended purpose, so the intended meaning is that the deception of Satan that the Hereafter is doubt is repelled either by traditional certainty, or by insight and witnessing from the aspect of the inner (Batin), and the believers with their tongues and with their beliefs if they neglect the commands of Allah the Exalted and abandon righteous works and engage in desires and disobediences, then they are partners with the disbelievers in this deception from the Fire even if after a while, but they are also among the deceived, for they acknowledged that the Hereafter is better than the world but they inclined to the world and preferred it, and mere faith is not sufficient for success. Allah the Exalted said: "And indeed, I am Forgiving to whoever repents and believes and does righteous work then is guided" and Allah the Exalted said: "Indeed, the mercy of Allah is near to the doers of good (Muhsinin)" then the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Ihsan (doing good) is that you worship Allah as if you see Him" and Allah the Exalted said: "By time, indeed, mankind is in loss, except for those who have believed and done righteous works and advised each other to truth and advised each other to patience." So the promise of forgiveness in all the Book of Allah the Exalted is tied to faith and righteous work together, not to faith alone, so these are also deceived, I mean those who are content with the world, joyful in it, indulgent in its pleasures, loving it. Those who hate death fearing the loss of worldly pleasures, not those who hate it fearing what comes after it, so this is an example of deception by the world from both disbelievers and believers altogether.

Then they will not be able to make a bequest, nor will they return to their families." And prayers and peace be upon Muhammad, His messenger, under whose banner the prophets march, and upon his family and his companions, the guided leaders, and the pleased masters, prayers equal in number to what has been of Allah's creation and what will be, and may the earlier and later ones attain its blessing, and abundant peace. After that, indeed anger is a flame of fire kindled from the fire of Allah that is ignited, which rises upon the hearts (Af'idah), and it is hidden in the recess of the heart (Fu'ad). It is like the ember hidden under ashes, and it is extracted by the concealed arrogance in the heart of every obstinate tyrant, like extracting fire from stone with iron. And it has been revealed to the observers by the light of certainty (Yaqin), that man has a vein extending to the accursed Satan (Shaytan), so whoever is provoked by the fire of anger has strengthened in him the kinship of Satan, as he said: "You created me from fire and created him from clay." ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
So whoever believes in Him is saved from this delusion (Ghurur), for the origin of this delusion (Ghurur) is ignorance of Allah and His attributes. For whoever knows Him does not feel secure from His scheme (Makr) nor is deceived by such false imaginings, and looks at Pharaoh, Haman, and Korah, and at the kings of the earth and what befell themâ€”how Allah initially bestowed favors upon them, then utterly destroyed them! So Allah the Exalted said: "Do you perceive any of them?" [Quran 19:98]. And Allah the Exalted has warned against His scheme (Makr) and gradual entrapment (Istidraj), saying: "So none feels secure from the scheme (Makr) of Allah except the losing people." [Quran 7:99] And He said: "And they devised a scheme (Makr), and We devised a scheme (Makr), while they were unaware." [Quran 27:50] And He the Mighty and Majestic said: "And they devised a scheme (Makr), and Allah devised a scheme (Makr), and Allah is the best of schemers (Makirin)." [Quran 3:54] And He said: "Indeed, they are planning a plan (Kaid), and I am planning a plan (Kaid). So give the disbelievers respite; give them respite a little." [Quran 86:15-17] Just as it is not permissible for a neglected servant to infer from the master's neglect of him and enabling him with blessings that the master loves him, rather he should beware that this might be a scheme (Makr) and plot (Kaid) from him, even though the master did not warn him of his own scheme (Makr), then how much more necessary is this regarding Allah the Exalted, with His warning of His gradual entrapment (Istidraj) being more appropriate. Therefore, whoever feels secure from the scheme (Makr) of Allah is deluded (Mughtarr), and the origin of this delusion (Ghurur) is that he infers from worldly blessings that he is honored by that Bestower, and it is possible that this is evidence of degradation, but that possibility does not accord with desire (Hawa). So Satan, through the medium of desire (Hawa), inclines the heart (Qalb) toward what accompanies it, which is believing that it indicates honor, and this is the definition of delusion (Ghurur).

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
Indeed, the word of the Almighty: **"Do they feel secure from the plan of Allah?"** [7:99]... So know that whoever takes spiritual knowledge [ma'rifa] from mere words and analogies, his stumbling will be frequent. And this example we give, though we present it, does not perfectly match our subject in every aspect. For the cause of overwhelming hope is knowledge [â€˜ilm] gained through experience: one knows through experience the soundness of the soil, its purity, the soundness of the seed, the soundness of the air, and the scarcity of destructive lightning strikes in those regions and others. The example for our matter, however, is a seed whose kind has never been tried, sown in a strange land the sower has not known or tested, in a country he does not know whether lightning is frequent or not. Such a sower, even if he exerts his utmost effort and brings forth all his capability, his hope [rajaâ€™] will not overcome his fear [khawf]. And the seed in our matter is faith [iman]; the conditions for its soundness are subtle. The earth is the heart [qalb], and its hidden recesses are malignant; its purification from hidden polytheism [shirk], hypocrisy [nifaq], and ostentation [riyaâ€™] is obscure, and the hidden traits within it are ambiguous. The blights are the appetites [shahawat] and the glitter of the world [dunya], and the heart's inclination towards them in the future, even if it is safe in the present. This is something not verified or known through experience, for causes may appear that cannot be withstood, and their like has not been experienced. The lightning strikes are the terrors of the agonies of death and the disturbance of belief at that timeâ€”their like has not been experienced. Then the harvest and attainment are upon departure from the Resurrection to Paradiseâ€”that has not been experienced. Whoever knows the realities [haqaâ€™iq] of these matters, if he is weak of heart, timid by nature, his fear will inevitably overcome his hope, as will be related in the states of the fearful among the Companions and the Successors. If he is strong of heart, firm of resolve, complete in knowledge [maâ€™rifa], his fear and hope become balanced. But as for his hope overcoming? No, never. Indeed, â€˜Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, would intensely scrutinize his heart until he would ask Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with him, if he recognized in him any traces of hypocrisy, since the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had specially entrusted him with the knowledge of the hypocrites. So who is it that can purify his heart from the hidden recesses of hypocrisy and concealed polytheism? And even if he believes his heart is pure from that, from where does he feel secure from the plan of Allah, the Exalted, in deluding him about his state and concealing his fault from him? And even if he is confident in that, from where is he confident of remaining upon that until the perfection of a good ending? For he, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, a man may perform the deeds of the people of Paradise for fifty years, until there remains between him and Paradise but a span," and in a narration: "but the measure of a camel's pause, then the decree overtakes him and he is sealed with the deed of the people of the Fire." And the measure of a camel's pause does not allow for a deed of the limbs; it is merely the measure of a fleeting thought that stirs in the heart at death, necessitating an evil ending. So how can one feel secure from that? Therefore, the utmost limit for the believer is that his fear and hope become balanced. The predominance of hope in most people is based on delusion and lack of true knowledge [maâ€™rifa]. For that reason, Allah, the Exalted, combined them in describing those He praised, saying: **"They supplicate their Lord in fear and eager hope"** [32:16], and the Almighty said: **"And they supplicate Us in hope and fear"** [21:90]. And where is the like of â€˜Umar, may Allah be pleased with him? The people existing in this timeâ€”all of themâ€”what is most wholesome for them is the predominance of fear, provided it does not lead them to despair [yaâ€™s], abandoning works, and cutting off hope for forgiveness, for that would become a cause for laziness in work and an invitation to plunge into disobedience. That is despair, and it is not fear. Indeed, fear is that which spurs one to work, clouds all appetites, agitates the heart from reclining towards the world [dunya], and calls it to turn away from the abode of delusion. That is the praiseworthy fear, not the whisper of the soul which has no effect in restraint and urging, nor the despair that leads to hopelessness. And Yahya ibn Muâ€™adh said: "Whoever worships Allah with pure fear drowns in seas of anxious thoughts. Whoever worships Him with pure hope wanders lost in the desert of delusion. Whoever worships Him with fear and hope walks straight on the path of remembrance." And Makhul al-Dimashqi said: "Whoever worships Allah with fear is a Kharijite. Whoever worships Him with hope is a Murjiâ€™ite. Whoever worships Him with love is a heretic. Whoever worships Him with fear, hope, and love is a monotheist." Therefore, combining these matters is necessary. The predominance of fear is the most wholesome, but *before* drawing near to death. As for at the time of death, the most wholesome is the predominance of hope and good expectation, for fear runs the course of a whip that spurs to work, and the time for work has ended for the one drawing near to death.

And the fear of the Prophets, despite the abundant blessings that flowed upon them, was because they did not feel secure from the plotting (makkara) of Allah the Exalted: 'So none feels secure from the plotting (makkara) of Allah except the people who are losers.' Until it was narrated that the Prophet and Gabriel, peace be upon them both, wept out of fear from Allah the Exalted, so Allah revealed to them: 'Why do you weep when I have given you security?' They said: 'And who feels secure from Your plotting (makkara)?' And it was as if they, since they knew that Allah is the Knower of the unseen and that they had no standing regarding the ultimate matters, did not feel secure that His saying 'I have given you security' might be a trial (ibtila') and a test (imtihana) for them and a plotting (makkara) against them, so that if their fear subsided, it would become apparent that they had felt secure from the plotting (makkara) and had not been true to their saying.

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
As for the blameworthy effects, they are like dark smoke that rises to the mirror of the Heart (Qalb) and continues to accumulate upon it time after time until it blackens and darkens and becomes completely veiled from Allah the Exalted, and this is the Sealing (Al-Tab') and the Rust (Al-Rayn). Allah the Exalted said: 'No! Rather, what they have earned has rusted upon their hearts.' And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'Or has it not been made clear to those who inherit the earth after its [former] people that if We willed, We could afflict them for their sins and seal over their hearts so they would not hear?' So He linked the lack of hearing to the sealing with sins, just as He linked hearing to God-consciousness (Taqwa), for He the Exalted said: 'And fear Allah and listen, and fear Allah, and Allah will teach you.' Whenever sins accumulate, the hearts are sealed, and at that point the Heart (Qalb) becomes blind to perceiving the Truth (Al-Haqq) and the rectitude of the religion, and it belittles the matter of the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah) and magnifies the matter of the Worldly Life (Al-Dunya), and its concern becomes restricted to it. So when its hearing is struck by the matter of the Hereafter and the dangers within it, it enters from one ear and exits from the other, and it does not settle in the Heart (Qalb) and does not move it to repentance (Al-Tawbah) and rectification. Those are the ones who have despaired of the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah) just as the disbelievers despair of the companions of the graves. And this is the meaning of the blackening of the Heart (Qalb) by sins, as articulated by the Quran and the Sunnah.

a.g: Those cities - We relate to you, [O Muhammad], some of their news. And certainly did their messengers come to them with clear proofs, but they were not to believe in that which they had denied before. Thus does Allah seal over the hearts of the disbelievers.
And We did not find for most of them any covenant; but indeed, We found most of them defiantly disobedient.
Then We sent after them Moses with Our signs to Pharaoh and his establishment, but they were unjust toward them. So see how was the end of the corrupters.
And Moses said, "O Pharaoh, I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds
[Who is] obligated not to say about Allah except the truth. I have come to you with clear evidence from your Lord, so send with me the Children of Israel."
[Pharaoh] said, "If you have come with a sign, then bring it forth, if you should be of the truthful."
So Moses threw his staff, and suddenly it was a serpent, manifest.
And he drew out his hand; thereupon it was white [with radiance] for the observers.
Said the eminent among the people of Pharaoh, "Indeed, this is a learned magician
Who wants to expel you from your land [through magic], so what do you instruct?"
They said, "Postpone [the matter of] him and his brother and send among the cities gatherers
Who will bring you every learned magician."
And the magicians came to Pharaoh. They said, "Indeed for us is a reward if we are the predominant."
He said, "Yes, and, [moreover], you will be among those made near [to me]."
They said, "O Moses, either you throw [your staff], or we will be the ones to throw [first]."
He said, "Throw," and when they threw, they bewitched the eyes of the people and struck terror into them, and they presented a great [feat of] magic.
And We inspired to Moses, "Throw your staff," and at once it devoured what they were falsifying.
So the truth was established, and abolished was what they were doing.
And Pharaoh and his people were overcome right there and became debased.
And the magicians fell down in prostration [to Allah].
They said, "We have believed in the Lord of the worlds,
The Lord of Moses and Aaron."
Said Pharaoh, "You believed in him before I gave you permission. Indeed, this is a conspiracy which you conspired in the city to expel therefrom its people. But you are going to know.
I will surely cut off your hands and your feet on opposite sides; then I will surely crucify you all."

a.g: They said, "Indeed, to our Lord we will return.
And you do not resent us except because we believed in the signs of our Lord when they came to us. Our Lord, pour upon us patience and let us die as Muslims [in submission to You]."

And the eminent among the people of Pharaoh said," Will you leave Moses and his people to cause corruption in the land and abandon you and your gods?" [Pharaoh] said, "We will kill their sons and keep their women alive; and indeed, we are subjugators over them."

Said Moses to his people, "Seek help through Allah and be patient. Indeed, the earth belongs to Allah. He causes to inherit it whom He wills of His servants. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous."

They said, "We have been harmed before you came to us and after you have come to us." He said, "Perhaps your Lord will destroy your enemy and grant you succession in the land and see how you will do."
And We certainly seized the people of Pharaoh with years of famine and a deficiency in fruits that perhaps they would be reminded.

But when good came to them, they said, "This is ours [by right]." And if a bad [condition] struck them, they saw an evil omen in Moses and those with him. Unquestionably, their fortune is with Allah, but most of them do not know.
And they said, "No matter what sign you bring us with which to bewitch us, we will not be believers in you."
So We sent upon them the flood and locusts and lice and frogs and blood as distinct signs, but they were arrogant and were a criminal people.

And when the punishment descended upon them, they said, "O Moses, invoke for us your Lord by what He has promised you. If you [can] remove the punishment from us, we will surely believe you, and we will send with you the Children of Israel."
But when We removed the punishment from them until a term which they were to reach, then at once they broke their word.
So We took retribution from them, and We drowned them in the sea because they denied Our signs and were heedless of them.

And We caused the people who had been oppressed to inherit the eastern regions of the land and the western ones, which We had blessed. And the good word of your Lord was fulfilled for the Children of Israel because of what they had patiently endured. And We destroyed [all] that Pharaoh and his people were producing and what they had been building.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
And Allah the Exalted has described the patient ones with attributes and mentioned patience in the Quran in over seventy places, and He attributed most degrees and goodnesses to patience and made them its fruit, as He the Mighty and Sublime said: 'And We made from them leaders guiding by Our command when they were patient' (Quran 32:24), and He the Exalted said: 'And the good word of your Lord was fulfilled upon the Children of Israel because of what they patiently endured' (Quran 7:137), and He the Exalted said: 'And We will surely give those who were patient their reward according to the best of what they used to do' (Quran 16:96), and He the Exalted said: 'Those will be given their reward twice for what they patiently endured' (Quran 28:54), and He the Exalted said: 'Indeed, the patient will be given their reward without account' (Quran 39:10). So there is no act of worship except that its reward is by measure and account except patience, and because fasting is from patience and it is half of patience, Allah the Exalted said: 'Fasting is for Me and I will reward it' (Hadith), so He attributed it to Himself from among all other acts of worship, and He promised the patient ones that He is with them, as He the Exalted said: 'And be patient, indeed Allah is with the patient' (Quran 8:46), and He made victory conditional upon patience, as He the Exalted said: 'Yes, if you are patient and conscious of Allah and they come upon you in this rage of theirs, your Lord will reinforce you with five thousand angels having marks' (Quran 3:125), and He gathered for the patient ones between matters He did not gather for others, as He the Exalted said: 'Those are the ones upon whom are prayers from their Lord and mercy, and those are the ones who are guided' (Quran 2:157). So guidance, mercy, and prayers are gathered for the patient ones, and enumerating all the verses in the station of patience would be lengthy.

a.g: And We took the Children of Israel across the sea; then they came upon a people intent in devotion to [some] idols of theirs. They said, "O Moses, make for us a god just as they have gods." He said, "Indeed, you are a people behaving ignorantly.

And when Moses arrived at Our appointed time and his Lord spoke to him, he said, "My Lord, show me [Yourself] that I may look at You." [Allah] said, "You will not see Me, but look at the mountain; if it should remain in place, then you will see Me." But when his Lord appeared to the mountain, He rendered it level, and Moses fell unconscious. And when he awoke, he said, "Exalted are You! I have repented to You, and I am the first of the believers."

a.g: Those who denied Our signs and the meeting of the Hereafter - their deeds have become worthless. Are they recompensed except for what they used to do?

And the people of Moses made, after [his departure], from their ornaments a calf - an image having a lowing sound. Did they not see that it could neither speak to them nor guide them to a way? They took it [for worship], and they were wrongdoers.
And when regret overcame them and they saw that they had gone astray, they said, "If our Lord does not have mercy upon us and forgive us, we will surely be among the losers."

And when Moses returned to his people, angry and grieved, he said, "How wretched is that by which you have replaced me after [my departure]. Were you impatient over the matter of your Lord?" And he threw down the tablets and seized his brother by [the hair of] his head, pulling him toward him. [Aaron] said, "O son of my mother, indeed the people oppressed me and were about to kill me, so let not the enemies rejoice over me and do not place me among the wrongdoing people."
[Moses] said, "My Lord, forgive me and my brother and admit us into Your mercy, for You are the most merciful of the merciful."
Indeed, those who took the calf [for worship] will obtain anger from their Lord and humiliation in the life of this world, and thus do We recompense the inventors [of falsehood].
But those who committed misdeeds and then repented after them and believed - indeed your Lord, thereafter, is Forgiving and Merciful.
And when the anger subsided in Moses, he took up the tablets; and in their inscription was guidance and mercy for those who are fearful of their Lord.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
And as for through the method of citation from the verses and reports, what has come regarding the excellence of fear is beyond enumeration, and sufficient as an indication of its excellence is that Allah the Exalted has gathered for those who fear guidance and mercy and knowledge and pleasure, and these are the collective stations of the people of the Gardens. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And guidance and mercy for those who are in awe of their Lord (yarhaboon).' And He the Exalted said: 'Only those fear Allah from among His servants who are knowledgeable (al-'ulama).' He described them with knowledge due to their awe. And He the Majestic and Exalted said: 'Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him; that is for whoever fears his Lord.' And everything that indicates the excellence of knowledge indicates the excellence of fear because fear is the fruit of knowledge. And therefore it came in the report of Moses, upon him the best of prayers and peace, and as for those who fear, then for them is the Highest Companion (al-Rafiq al-A'la) in which they are not shared. So see how He singled them out with the companionship of the Highest Companion, and that is because they are the knowledgeable ones (al-'ulama), and the knowledgeable ones have the rank of companionship with the prophets because they are the inheritors of the prophets, and the companionship of the Highest Companion is for the prophets and those who join them. And therefore (when the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was given the choice during his terminal illness between remaining in the world and coming to Allah the Exalted, he would say: 'I ask You for the Highest Companion.') So then, if one looks at its producer, it is knowledge, and if one looks at its fruit, it is scrupulousness (al-wara') and piety (al-taqwa). And what has come regarding their excellences is not hidden, until indeed the outcome has become marked with piety, specifically designated by it, just as praise has become specifically designated for Allah the Exalted and prayer for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, until it is said: 'Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds, and the outcome is for the pious, and prayers upon our master Muhammad, peace be upon him, and all his family.' And Allah the Exalted has specifically designated piety with addition to Himself, so He the Exalted said: 'Their flesh and their blood do not reach Allah, but your piety reaches Him.'

Indeed, the people in the earlier eras used to consistently perform acts of worship and give what they gave while their hearts were fearful that they were returning to their Lord, fearing for their souls (Nafs), and they were throughout the night and day in obedience to Allah, exaggerating in God-consciousness (Taqwa) and caution from doubts and desires, and weeping over themselves in seclusions. If this matter were attained by wishful thinking and obtained easily, then why then was the weeping, fear, and grief of those? If one of them does good, he says: 'It will be accepted from me,' and if he does evil, he says: 'I will be forgiven.'" So he informed that they place hope (Tam') in the position of fear due to their ignorance of the warnings of the Quran and what is in it. And similarly, He informed about the Christians when He the Exalted said: "Then there succeeded after them a succession who inherited the Book, taking the enjoyment of this lower world and saying: 'It will be forgiven for us.'" And its meaning is that they "inherited the Book," meaning they are scholars, "and take the enjoyment of this lower world," meaning their desires from the worldly life, whether it was unlawful (Haram) or lawful (Halal). And He the Exalted said: "And for him who fears the standing before his Lord are two gardens - that is for whoever feared My standing and feared and worshiped." And the Quran from its beginning to its end is warning and causing fear; no one reflects in it except that his grief lengthens and his fear magnifies if he is a believer in what is in it. And you see people reciting it like this, emitting the letters from their points of articulation and disputing over their lowering, raising, and nominating as if they are reciting poetry from the poems of the Arabs, not caring to pay attention to its meanings and acting upon what is in it. And is there in the world delusion (Ghurur) greater than this? Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
Therefore, Allah the Exalted said: 'And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam from their loins their descendants and made them testify concerning themselves, [saying to them], "Am I not your Lord?" They said, "Yes, we have testified."' [Quran 7:172] The intended meaning is the affirmation of their souls (Nafs) not the affirmation of tongues, for they divided in the affirmation of tongues where tongues and persons are found into affirmers and deniers. Therefore, Allah the Exalted said: 'And if you asked them, "Who created them?" they would surely say, "Allah."' [Quran 43:87] Its meaning is that if you consider their states, their souls (Nafs) and their inner selves (Bawatin) testify to that by the natural disposition (Fitrah) of Allah upon which He created people, meaning every human is created with natural disposition (Fitrah) upon faith in Allah the Exalted, indeed upon knowledge of things as they are, meaning they are as if embedded in it due to the proximity of their preparedness for perception. Then, since faith is firmly rooted in the souls (Nafs) by natural disposition (Fitrah), people divided into two groups: those who turned away and forgot, and they are the disbelievers (Kuffar), and those who pondered with their thoughts (Khatir) and remembered, so it was as if one carried a testimony then forgot it due to heedlessness (Ghaflah) then remembered it. Therefore, Allah the Exalted said: 'That they may remember' [Quran 7:174], 'And that those of understanding may remember' [Quran 38:29], 'And remember the favor of Allah upon you and His covenant with which He bound you' [Quran 5:7], 'And We have certainly made the Quran easy for remembrance, so is there any who will remember?' [Quran 54:17]; and naming this pattern remembrance (Tadhakkur) is not far-fetched, as if remembrance (Tadhakkur) is of two types: one is to remember an image that was present in existence in his heart (Qalb) but disappeared after the other existence. The other is to remember an image that was embedded in him by natural disposition (Fitrah), and these are truths apparent to the observer by the light of insight (Bassirah), heavy upon one who is dominated by hearsay, his saying 'is dominated' from circulation, meaning hearing and imitation become prevalent.

And it is not hidden that the likeness of every thing is drawn to it, and that the Soul (Nafs) whose inclination is toward the craft of shoemaking more than its inclination toward the craft of writing, then he is more similar in his essence to shoemakers than to writers. And indeed, 'understanding' (Fiqh) and 'comprehension' (Fahm) in the language are two names with one meaning, and one only speaks of it in terms of customary usage, ancient and modern.

a.g: And to Allah belong the best names, so invoke Him by them. And leave [the company of] those who practice deviation concerning His names. They will be recompensed for what they have been doing.
And among those We created is a community which guides by truth and thereby establishes justice.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
And the cure for this delusion (Ghurur) is knowing the signs of honor (Karama) and humiliation (Hawan) either through insight (Basira) or through imitation (Taqleed). As for insight, it is by knowing how turning toward worldly desires distances one from Allah and how distancing from them brings one closer to Allah, and one perceives that through inspiration (Ilham) in the stations of the knowers (Arifin) and the friends (Awliya), and its explanation is among the sciences of unveiling (Mukashafa) and is not suitable for the science of transaction. "And as for knowing it through the way of imitation and belief (Tasdeeq)," it is to have faith in the Book of Allah the Exalted and believe His Messenger. And He the Exalted has said: "Do they think that what We extend to them of wealth and children, We hasten for them in good things? Rather, they do not perceive." And He the Exalted said: "And those who deny Our signs - We will progressively lead them [to destruction] from where they do not know." And He the Exalted said: "We opened to them the gates of every thing until, when they rejoiced in that which they were given, We seized them suddenly, and at once they were in despair." And in the interpretation of His saying the Exalted "We will progressively lead them [to destruction] from where they do not know," it is that whenever they commit a sin, We grant them a blessing to increase their delusion. And He the Exalted said: "We only delay them that they may increase in sin." And He the Exalted said: "And never think that Allah is unaware of what the wrongdoers do. He only delays them for a Day when eyes will stare [in horror]." And other than that which has come in the Book of Allah the Exalted and the Sunnah of His Messenger. So whoever believes in it is freed from this delusion, for the origin of this delusion is ignorance of Allah and His attributes. For whoever knows Him does not feel secure from His plan (Makr) nor is deceived by such false imaginings, and looks at Pharaoh, Haman, and Korah, and at the kings of the earth and what happened to them - how Allah was good to them initially, then destroyed them utterly! So He the Exalted said: "Do you perceive of them anyone?" the verse. And Allah the Exalted has warned of His plan and gradual leading, saying: "So no one feels secure from the plan of Allah except the losing people." And He the Exalted said: "And they planned a plan, and We planned a plan, while they perceived not." And He the Mighty and Majestic said: "And they planned, and Allah planned. And Allah is the best of planners." And He the Exalted said: "Indeed, they are planning a plan, and I am planning a plan. So allow time for the disbelievers. Leave them awhile." ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
If you say: From where did the speaker know what Iblis said, when he neither witnessed Iblis nor was informed by him? Then know that the possessors of hearts (Arbab al-Qulub) are unveiled to the secrets of the dominion (Malakut) sometimes through inspiration (Ilham) by it occurring to them through arrival upon them from where they do not know, sometimes through truthful vision (Ru'ya al-Sadiqa), and sometimes in wakefulness through unveiling of meanings (Kashf al-Ma'ani) by witnessing examples as occurs in dreams. This is the highest of degrees, and it is from the high degrees of prophethood, just as the truthful vision is one part of forty-six parts of prophethood. Beware that your portion of this knowledge be denial of what exceeds the limit of your incapacity, for in it perished the pretentious among the scholars who claim they have encompassed the sciences of intellects. So ignorance is better than an intellect that calls to denial of such matters for the friends of Allah (Awliya' Allah) the Exalted. And whoever denies that for the friends, it necessitates for him denial of the prophets, and he would be completely outside the religion. Some of the knowers (Arifin) said: Indeed, the substitutes (Abdal) have been cut off in the extremities of the earth and concealed from the sight of the public because they cannot bear to look at the scholars of the time, for they are, according to them, ignorant of Allah the Exalted, while they are, according to themselves and according to the ignorant, scholars. Sahl al-Tustari, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Indeed, among the greatest sins is ignorance of ignorance, looking to the common people, and listening to the speech of the people of heedlessness (Ghafila). And every scholar who delves into the world, it is not fitting to heed his saying; rather, he should be suspected in everything he says, because every person delves into what he loves and repels what does not agree with his beloved. And for that reason, Allah the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And those who deny Our signs, We will lead them on from where they do not know' (Quran 7:182), and 'And do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance (Dhikr) and who follows his desire (Hawa) and whose affair is ever [in] neglect'.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
Praise be to Allah, upon whose forgiveness and mercy none rely except the hopeful, and none fear the evil of His anger and His might except the fearful, who gradually leads His servants from where they do not know, and has subjected them to desires and commanded them to abandon what they desire, and has tested them with anger and obligated them to suppress rage in what angers them, then has surrounded them with hardships and pleasures and has given them respite to see how they act, and has tested them with their love to know their truthfulness in what they claim, and has made known to them that nothing is hidden from Him of what they conceal and what they reveal, and has warned them that He may seize them suddenly while they are unaware, so He said: "They await not but a single blast which will seize them while they are disputing. Then they will not be able to make a bequest, nor will they return to their families." And prayers and peace be upon Muhammad, His messenger, under whose banner the prophets march, and upon his family and his companions, the guided leaders, and the pleased masters, prayers equal in number to what has been of Allah's creation and what will be, and may the first and the last attain its blessing, and abundant peace.

And the cure for this delusion (Ghurur) is knowing the signs of honor (Karama) and humiliation (Hawan) either through insight (Bassira) or through imitation (Taqleed). As for insight, it is by knowing how turning towards the desires of the world distances one from Allah and how distancing from them brings one closer to Allah, and one perceives that through inspiration (Ilham) in the stations of the knowers (Arifeen) and the friends (Awliya), and its explanation is among the sciences of unveiling (Mukashafa) and is not suitable for the science of transaction (Mu'amala). 'And as for knowing it through the way of imitation and belief (Tasdeeq),' it is to have faith in the Book of Allah the Exalted and believe His Messenger. And He the Exalted has said: 'Do they think that what We extend to them of wealth and children, We hasten for them in good things? Rather, they do not perceive.' And He the Exalted has said: 'We will gradually lead them [to destruction] from where they do not know.' And He the Exalted has said: 'We opened to them the doors of every thing until, when they rejoiced in that which they were given, We seized them suddenly, and at once they were in despair.' And in the interpretation of His the Exalted saying 'We will gradually lead them [to destruction] from where they do not know,' it is that whenever they commit a sin, We grant them a blessing to increase their delusion. And He the Exalted has said: 'We only extend time for them that they may increase in sin.' And He the Exalted has said: 'And never think that Allah is unaware of what the wrongdoers do. He only delays them for a Day when eyes will stare [in horror].' And other than that from what has come in the Book of Allah the Exalted and the Sunnah of His Messenger. So whoever believes in it is freed from this delusion, for the origin of this delusion is ignorance of Allah and His attributes, for whoever knows Him does not feel secure from His plan (Makr) nor is deceived by such false imaginings, and looks at Pharaoh, Haman, and Korah and at the kings of the earth and what happened to themâ€”how Allah bestowed favor upon them initially then destroyed them utterly! So He the Exalted said: 'Do you perceive of them anyone?' the verse. And Allah the Exalted has warned of His plan and gradual leading, saying: 'So none feels secure from the plan of Allah except the losing people.' And He the Exalted has said: 'And they planned a plan, and We planned a plan, while they perceived not.' And He the Mighty and Majestic has said: 'And they planned, and Allah planned. And Allah is the best of planners.' And He the Exalted has said: 'Indeed, they are planning a plan, and I am planning a plan. So allow time for the disbelievers. Deal with them gently [for a while].' So just as it is not permissible for the neglected servant to infer from the master's neglect of him and enabling him of blessings upon the master's love, rather he should be cautious that it might be a plan and scheme from him, even though the master did not warn him of his own plan, then how much more must that be in the right of Allah the Exalted with His warning.

Indeed, among the strongest incitements to anger [ghadab] for most of the ignorant is their naming of anger as courage [shaja'a], manliness, self-respect ['izzat nafs], and high ambition, and their labeling it with praiseworthy titlesâ€”this is foolishness and ignorance, until the soul [nafs] inclines towards it and approves of it. This can be reinforced by recounting the intensity of anger from great figures in the context of praising courage, and souls [nufus] are inclined to emulate great figures, so anger is stirred in the heart [qalb] because of it. To name this self-respect and courage is ignorance; rather, it is a sickness of the heart [qalb] and a deficiency of intellect ['aql], and it is due to the weakness and deficiency of the soul [nafs]. A sign that it is from the weakness of the soul [nafs] is that the sick person is quicker to anger than the healthy, the woman is quicker to anger than the man, the child is quicker to anger than the grown man, the weak old man is quicker to anger than the middle-aged man, and the one with bad character and vile traits is quicker to anger than the possessor of virtues. Thus, the vile person becomes angry for his desire [shahwa] if a morsel escapes him, and for his miserliness if a grain escapes him, to the point that he becomes angry with his family, his children, and his companions. Rather, the strong one is he who controls himself during anger, as the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "The strong is not the one who overcomes people by his strength. Rather, the strong is the one who controls himself while in anger." Rather, this ignorant one should be treated by reciting to him the accounts of the people of forbearance [hilm] and pardon ['afw], and what was deemed good from them in suppressing rage [ghayz], for that is transmitted from the Prophets, the saints [awliya'], the wise, the scholars, and the great, virtuous kings. And the opposite of that is transmitted from the Kurds, the Turks, the ignorant, and the foolish who have no intellects and no virtue in them. **Explanation of Treating Anger After Its Agitation** What we have mentioned is the severing of the sources of anger and the cutting off of its causes so that it does not stir. If a cause for its agitation occurs, then at that point one must be deliberate so that its owner is not compelled to act upon it in the blameworthy manner. Anger, when agitated, is only treated with the compound of knowledge ['ilm] and action ['amal]. As for knowledge ['ilm], it is six matters: **The First:** That he reflects upon the reports we will present regarding the virtue of suppressing rage [ghayz], pardon ['afw], forbearance [hilm], and endurance, so he desires its reward. Thus, the intensity of his craving for the reward of suppression prevents him from seeking satisfaction and revenge, and his rage [ghayz] is extinguished. Malik bin Aws bin Al-Hadthan said: "Umar became angry with a man and ordered him to be struck. I said, 'O Commander of the Faithful, *"Hold to forgiveness; enjoin what is good; and turn away from the ignorant."*' So Umar would say, *'Hold to forgiveness; enjoin what is good; and turn away from the ignorant,'* and he would contemplate the verse, and he was one who halted at the Book of God. Whenever it was recited to him, he would ponder over it greatly. So he pondered over it and released the man."

Know that the meaning of forgiveness (Al-'Afw) is that one is entitled to a right but waives it and absolves from punishment or penalty, and it is different from forbearance (Al-Hilm) and suppressing anger (Kazm Al-Ghaiz); therefore we have singled it out. Allah the Exalted said: "Take forgiveness (Al-'Afw) and command with what is recognized as good (Al-'Urf) and turn away from the ignorant ones (Al-Jahilin)." And Allah the Exalted said: "And that you forgive is nearer to piety (Al-Taqwa)." And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Three things - by the One in Whose Hand is my soul - if I were to swear an oath, I would swear upon them: No wealth decreases from charity (Sadaqah), so give charity; and no man forgives an injustice seeking by it the Face of Allah except that Allah increases him in honor (Izz) on the Day of Resurrection; and no man opens upon himself the door of begging except that Allah opens upon him the door of poverty." And he (peace be upon him) said: "Humility (Al-Tawadu') does not increase the servant except in elevation, so be humble and Allah will elevate you; and forgiveness (Al-'Afw) does not increase the servant except in honor (Izz), so forgive and Allah will honor you; and charity (Al-Sadaqah) does not increase wealth except in abundance, so give charity and Allah will have mercy on you." And Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: "I never saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) seeking retaliation for an injustice done to him as long as it did not violate the prohibitions of Allah, but if something from the prohibitions of Allah was violated, he was the most severe among them in anger regarding that, and he was never given a choice between two matters except that he chose the easiest of them as long as it was not a sin." And Uqbah said: "I met the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) one day and I hastened to him and took his hand, or he hastened to me and took my hand, and he said: 'O Uqbah, shall I not inform you of the best character traits of the people of this world and the Hereafter: You maintain ties with one who cuts you off, you give to one who deprives you, and you forgive one who wrongs you.'" And he (peace be upon him) said: "Moses (peace be upon him) said: 'O Lord, which of Your servants is most honorable to You?' He said: 'The one who, when he has power, forgives.'" Likewise, Abu Al-Darda was asked about the most honorable of people, and he said: "The one who forgives when he has power, so forgive."

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Disciplining the Soul
And if he repels all the whisperings and returns the Soul (Nafs) to this word, whisperings come to him from this word, and they are: What is it? And what is the meaning of our saying: Allah? And for what meaning was He a deity (Ilah) and was worshipped? And there befalls him at that time thoughts that open upon him the door of reflection, and perhaps there comes to him from the whisperings of Satan what is disbelief and innovation. And however much he is averse to that and prepared to remove it from the Heart (Qalb), it does not harm him. And they are divided into what he knows decisively that Allah the Exalted is free from it, but Satan casts that in his heart and runs it on his thought, so his condition is that he should care about it and flee to the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah the Exalted and beseech Him to repel it from him, as Allah the Exalted said: "And if an incitement from Satan incites you, then seek refuge in Allah. Indeed, He is Hearing, Knowing." And He said: "Indeed, those who fear Allah, when an impulse from Satan touches them, they remember, and at once they see clearly." And into what he doubts about, then he should present that to his spiritual guide (Shaykh), rather everything he finds in his heart from the states of slackness or vigor or attention to an attachment or truthfulness in intention, then he should manifest that to his spiritual guide (Shaykh), and conceal it from others so that he does not inform anyone about it. Then his spiritual guide (Shaykh) looks at his condition and contemplates his intelligence and cleverness, so if he knows that if he leaves him and commands him with reflection, he awakens from himself to the reality of the Truth, then he should refer him to reflection and command him to adhere to it until there is cast in his heart from the light what unveils to him its reality. And if he knows that that is from what one like him cannot bear, he returns him to the decisive belief with what his heart can bear from admonition and that is evidence close to his understanding. And it is built that the spiritual guide (Shaykh) should be meticulous and gentle with him, for these are the perils of the path and places of its dangers.

So the likeness of faith in it is like a plant that pure water nourishes, and the likeness of hypocrisy in it is like an ulcer that pus and discharge nourish, so whichever of the two nourishments overcomes him, he is judged by it, and in a narration: it took him away. It is incumbent upon the servant (Al-Abd) to pause at every thought that occurs to him to know whether it is from the inspiration of the angel (Lamat Al-Malak) or from the whisper of the devil (Lamat Al-Shaytan), and to examine it deeply with the eye of insight (Al-Basira) not with the desire (Hawa) of the natural disposition (Al-Tab'), nor can one perceive it except with the light of God-consciousness (Al-Taqwa) and insight (Al-Basira) and abundance of knowledge, as Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, those who are God-conscious (Al-Muttaqun) - when an impulse from Satan touches them, they remember (Tadhakkaru) [Allah] and at once they have insight (Mubsirun).' That is, they return to the light of knowledge, so then they have insight (Mubsirun), meaning the confusion is unveiled for them. As for one who does not satisfy himself with God-consciousness (Al-Taqwa), his natural disposition (Al-Tab') inclines to submitting to its deception by following desire (Al-Hawa), so his error increases in it and his destruction hastens while he is unaware. And concerning their like, He the Exalted said: 'And there will appear to them from Allah that which they had not taken into account.' It is said: they are deeds they thought were good deeds, but they are evil deeds.

And therefore Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, those who are God-fearing (ittaqaw) when a passing thought (ta'if) from Satan touches them, they remember (tadhakkaru), then indeed they become seeing (mubsirun).' He specified that for the God-fearing (muttaqin). So the likeness of Satan is like a hungry dog that approaches you. If there is no bread or meat before you, then it is repelled by you saying to it: 'Go away!' Mere sound repels it. But if there is meat before you and it is hungry, then it attacks the meat and is not repelled by mere speech. So the Heart (Qalb) empty from the sustenance of Satan is repelled from it by mere Remembrance (Dhikr). As for the desire (shahwa) when it overcomes the Heart, it pushes the reality of the Remembrance to the peripheries of the Heart, so it does not reach its core (sawad), and Satan settles in the core of the Heart. But as for the hearts of the God-fearing (muttaqin), empty from caprice (hawa) and blameworthy traits, Satan approaches them not for desires but because of their emptiness due to heedlessness (ghafla) from the Remembrance. So when it returns to the Remembrance, Satan retreats. And evidence for that is His saying: 'So seek refuge in Allah from Satan the accursed,' and the rest of the reports and verses that have come regarding the Remembrance.

And nothing erases the whispering (waswasa) of the Satan (Shaytan) from the Heart (Qalb) except the remembrance (dhikr) of something other than what he whispers about, because when the remembrance of something occurs in the Heart, what was previously in it disappears. However, everything besides Allah the Exalted and besides what is connected to Him may also be a field for the Satan, and the remembrance of Allah is what secures his side and makes known that there is no field for the Satan in it. And nothing is treated except by its opposite, and the opposite of all the whisperings of the Satan is the remembrance of Allah through seeking refuge (isti'adha) and disavowing power and strength, which is the meaning of your saying: 'I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan' and 'There is no power nor strength except with Allah, the Most High, the Most Great.' And that is not within the capability except of the God-fearing (muttaqun) upon whom the remembrance of Allah the Exalted predominates. Indeed, the Satan only circles around them at times of lapses (faltat) by way of stealth. Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, those who fear Allah (ittaqaw) - when an impulse (ta'if) from Satan touches them, they remember (tadhakkaru) and then they see clearly (mubsirun).' And Mujahid said regarding the meaning of the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'From the evil of the whisperer (waswas) who withdraws (khannas)' - he said: 'He spreads out over the Heart, so when Allah the Exalted is remembered, he withdraws (khanasa) and contracts, and when one is heedless (ghafil), he spreads out over his heart.' So the chasing away between the remembrance of Allah the Exalted and the whispering of the Satan is like the chasing away between light (nur) and darkness (zalam), and between night (layl) and day (nahar). And due to their opposition, Allah the Exalted said: 'Satan has gained mastery over them and made them forget the remembrance of Allah.'

And He, the Exalted, said: 'And remember your Lord (Rabb) within your Soul (Nafs) with humility (Tadarru') and fear (Khifah) and without loudness in speech in the morning (Ghuduww) and the evening (Asal) and do not be among the heedless (Ghafilin).' And He, the Exalted, said: 'And the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah is greater.' Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: It has two aspects: one is that the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah, the Exalted, for you is greater than your remembrance of Him, and the other is that the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah is greater than every worship besides it, among other verses.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Prayer
(The Virtue of Humble Devotion [khushu']) Indeed, Allah the Exalted says: "And establish prayer for My remembrance [dhikri]" (Ta-Ha: 14). And He the Exalted says: "And do not be among the heedless [ghafilin]" (Al-A'raf: 205). And He the Mighty and Majestic says: "Do not approach prayer while you are intoxicated [sukara] until you know what you are saying" (An-Nisa': 43). It is said: intoxicated from the multitude of concerns, and it is said: from the love of the world [dunya]. And Wahb said the intended meaning is its apparent meaning, so in it is an alert to the intoxication of the world [dunya], for He stated the reason therein, saying: "until you know what you are saying" (An-Nisa': 43). And how many a person prays who has not drunk wine, yet he does not know what he is saying in his prayer. And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever prays two units [rak'atayn] without entertaining in them any thought of the world [dunya], his previous sins are forgiven for him." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, prayer is composed of humility [tamasukun], lowliness, earnest supplication, sighing, regret, and placing your hands [in supplication] while saying: O Allah, O Allah. So whoever does not do that, then it is deficient." And it is narrated from Allah, glorified be He, in the previous scriptures that He said: "I do not accept the prayer of every person who prays. I only accept the prayer of one who humbles himself before My majesty, does not act arrogantly towards My servants, and feeds the hungry poor for My sake." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Prayer was only prescribed, and the command for Hajj, circumambulation, and the rites of sacrifice were only instituted for the establishment of the remembrance [dhikr] of Allah the Exalted. So if there is not in your heart [qalb] for the One Remembered [madhkur], who is the intended goal and objective, any majesty or awe, then what is the value of your remembrance [dhikr]?" And he, peace be upon him, said to the one he advised: "And when you pray, pray the prayer of one bidding farewell [mawdi']." Meaning: bidding farewell to his soul [nafs], bidding farewell to his desire [hawa], bidding farewell to his lifespan, journeying to his Master, as He the Mighty and Majestic says: "O mankind, indeed you are laboring towards your Lord with [your] labor, and you will meet Him" (Al-Inshiqaq: 6). And He the Exalted says: "And fear Allah; and Allah teaches you" (Al-Baqarah: 282). And He the Exalted says: "And fear Allah and know that you will meet Him" (Al-Baqarah: 223). And he, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever is not prevented by his prayer from immorality and wrongdoing, increases in nothing from Allah except distance." And prayer is an intimate discourse [munajat]; how can it be with heedlessness [ghaflah]? And Bakr ibn 'Abdullah said: "O son of Adam, if you wish to enter upon your Master without permission and speak to Him without an interpreter, you may enter." It was said: "And how is that?" He said: "Perfect your ablution and enter your prayer niche [mihrab], and then you have entered upon your Master without permission and spoken to Him without an interpreter." And from 'A'ishah, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, would converse with us and we would converse with him. But when the time for prayer arrived, it was as if he did not know us and we did not know him," due to his preoccupation with the majesty of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic.
